awd_titl_txt: Improving the Effectiveness of Organizational Knowledge Transfer Through Social Media Use
awd_abstract_narration:
An organization's ability to help employees share knowledge with one another is directly related to its innovativeness, its ability to grow, and its ability to retain top talent. However, knowledge sharing remains a problem for many large organizations. Sometimes, problems of knowledge sharing occur because the knowledge itself is sticky; it requires deep contextual understanding to decode and apply. Other times, knowledge is difficult to transfer because individuals do not have the correct intensity of relationships (strong or weak) for the type of knowledge that needs to be transferred (tacit or explicit) such that individuals are unwilling to take the time and make the effort to teach a colleague something they do not know. In other cases, the problem is much simpler: People within the organization don't know what other people in the organization know and are therefore unable to seek or share with them.

The goal of this study is to understand how new enterprise social media can help to improve at least two important aspects of knowledge sharing: Helping people find the knowledge they need and helping them to build the correct kinds of relationships necessary to transfer certain kinds of knowledge. As organizations spend money and time on the implementation of these new technologies in an attempt to increase worker productivity, it seems timely and important to understand not only if such tools can overcome perennial problems associated with effective knowledge sharing, but also to elucidate the mechanisms by which such technologies affect knowledge sharing practices. In short, this research stands to unveil what happens when organizational communications that were once private become public and the consequences that this communication visibility can have for the organization as a whole. This research has high-impact potential for education, labor, and business policies as it considers strategies for retooling and reshaping the communication environments of organizations that are becoming increasingly distributed.

por.por_cntn:
As occurs with most new communication technologies, there is a great optimism that enterprise social networking tools will revolutionize the way that work takes place within contemporary organizations. In one of the most striking examples, the authors of recent report by the McKinsey Global Institute suggest that enterprise social networking site use in the workplace could result in up to $1.3 trillion of annual value across the financial services, consumer packaged goods, professional services, and advanced manufacturing sectors, and that knowledge workers in these sectors who use enterprise social networking tools for internal communication and collaboration have the potential to increase their productivity by more than 20%  

 Taking a more measured and focused view, the goal of this study was to explore whether enterprise social networking tools can help improve one important organizational activity: internal knowledge sharing. Effective internal knowledge sharing is tremendously important for organizations. Organizations that are able to get quality knowledge to the right people at the right time tend to be more innovative , have more satisfied employees  and are able to bring products and services to market faster than competitors . For these reasons, intraorganizational knowledge sharing and organizational learning are increasingly popular topics of study for organizational theorists at both micro and macro levels of analysis, Consequently, if enterprise social networking technologies can improve intraorganizational knowledge sharing, elucidating the mechanisms by which such improvement occurs will have important practical consequences for organizational managers and important theoretical consequences for organizational scientists.

Through data collection in three diverse settings, i developed and validated  a theory of communication visibility, which suggests that social technologies that make direct interpersonal communications (primarily dyadic) visible to others in the organization can have important benefits for internal knowledge sharing. These benefits are of at least two types. First, through exposure to the work-related communications over their co-workers (communications of which they, themselves, are not apart) people can develop important organizational meta-knowledge: knowledge of what and whom other people in the organization know. This development of meta-knowledge may help improve the speed at which individuals can find the knowledge they need and get access to it. Second, through the use of enterprise social networking tools, people can communicate with others, with whom they do not have regular occasions to interact, in ways that provide publicly visible traces of their relationship history. These visible traces (and the social pressure to honor them that comes from a public display) can help to increase the perceived closeness of a relationship such that the appropriate tie strength exists for particular kinds of knowledge transfer.

So far, papers that have cited the work coming from this grant have numbered more than 400, according to Google Scholar. I have also been in contact with many companies who have read the work and who have sought counsel on how to use social tools to enhance knowledge sharing in their organizations through communication visibility.
